Ringed Seals also range widely into adjacent seas being found in the Bering Sea, Chukchi Sea, Beaufort Sea, Canadian Arctic Archipelago, Hudson Bay, Hudson Strait, Davis Strait, and Greenland, Barents, White, Kara, Laptev, and East Siberian Seas, and they occasionally range into some lake and river systems in Northern Canada (Heide-Jørgensen and Lydersen 1998). Separate subspecies occur in the Baltic Sea, Lake Ladoga in the Russian Federation, Lake Saimaa in Finland, and the Sea of Okhotsk (Frost and Lowry 1981, Reeves 1998). Extralimital records for Ringed Seals extend far south on both sides of the Atlantic, to New Jersey USA in the west and Portugal in the east. In the Pacific, vagrants have been recorded south to the Zhejiang in China and southern California USA (Rice 1998).
useTrade:
Humans have hunted Ringed Seals in the Arctic since the arrival of people to the region millennia ago (e.g., Murdoch 1893, Riewe and Amsden 1979). They are a fundamental subsistence food item for most coastal dwelling northern indigenous peoples. Reeves et al. (1998) reported a combined estimate of 10,000 taken per year from the Bering, Chukchi, and western Beaufort Seas by Russians and Alaska Natives. They also estimated that the annual removal of Ringed Seals in the Canadian Arctic was in the “high tens of thousands”, and that in the 1980s, including animals killed and lost, the harvest was between 60,000 and 80,000, and may have exceeded 100,000 in some years. Another substantial annual harvest occurs in Greenland with nearly 100,000 taken per year in the 1970s and approximately 70,000 taken annually in the early1990s (Teilmann and Kapel 1998).

Commercial harvests of Ringed Seals in the early to mid-20th century were sometimes large and probably had significant local impacts on the respective populations. Harvest statistics reported for western Russia by Belikov and Boltunov (1998) suggest that maximum catches earlier in the 20th century exceeded the total allowable catches (TACs) significantly, with harvests of up to 8,900 in the White Sea (1912), 13,200 in the Russian Barents Sea (1962), and 13,200 in the Kara Sea (1933). Those harvests are thought to have dropped considerably in recent decades, though there are no available data. Reporting of harvest statistics and enforcement of TACs is difficult to manage in outlying areas, and the harvest of Ringed Seals in eastern Russia is largely unknown.

Although Ringed Seals in the Baltic and Lakes Ladoga and Saimaa were hunted in the past, hunting is no longer allowed (Sipilä and Hyvärinen 1998, Härkönen et al. 1998).
conservationActions: Ringed Seals are protected by a variety of laws and quotas in different parts of their range, but even within Europe the legal provisions are not always being fully implemented in domestic law (Wilson et al. 2001). The population in Lake Saimaa has been protected since 1955, and additional protection has been afforded via the establishment of two national parks within the lake, and regulation of shoreline development. Similarly, the hunting of Seals in Lake Ladoga was prohibited in 1980 (Sipilä and Hyvärinen 1998). In the USA, the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 allows Ringed Seals to be harvested only by Alaskan Native hunters for subsistence purposes, and that Act generally prohibits all other forms of taking except where specifically permitted. In 2012, the Arctic, Okhotsk, and Baltic subspecies were listed as threatened, and the Ladoga subspecies was listed as endangered, under the US Endangered Species Act; the Saimaa subspecies was listed as endangered in 1993. State Nature Reserves at Franz Josef Land and in the White and Kara seas protect large areas of Ringed Seal habitat in the western Russian Arctic, and quotas and licensing of hunting have been in place in various parts of the Russian Federation for decades (Belikov and Boltunov 1998). Baltic Ringed Seals were protected from all killing by the Soviet Union in 1980, by Sweden in 1986, and by Finland in 1988 (Härkönen et al. 1998).

rationale: Brachypleura novaezeelandiae has a wide distribution from the Persian Gulf through the Indian Ocean to the western Pacific Ocean. It is harvested as a food source, as a source of fish meal, and constitutes part of the discarded bycatch of demersal trawl fisheries. Quantitative data to estimate impacts of these activities on the population are not available. However, at this time, these activities are not thought to be significantly impacting this species across its entire range. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern. Further research to monitor harvest levels and population size and trend of this species is recommended to improve future conservation assessments.
habitat: This marine, demersal species inhabits sand and mud substrates of coastal (i.e., near river mouths) and offshore areas (Hensley 2001, Satapoomin 2011). It consumes benthic organisms (Carpenter et al. 1997, Hensley 2001). The maximum total length is 14 cm, though most specimens are not larger than 12 cm (Hensley 2001). Off peninsular Malaysia, Abu Talib et al. (2003) estimated various life history and mortality parameters, including: Lꚙ =  21.9 cm; K yr -1 = 0.71; mortality parameters Z yr -1 = 2.43; F yr -1 = 1.61; and exploitation ratio (E=F/Z) = 0.34.
threats: The extent to which this species is taken in trawl fisheries is unknown and therefore it is unclear whether this results in significant impacts to the population.
population: Population data are limited. It is a common and sometimes abundant species. For example, within the southern South China Sea, 1,714 specimens were collected off eastern peninsular Malaysia during a 1998 survey to estimate growth, mortality, and exploitation of demersal species, including B. novaezeelandiae (Abu Talib et al. 2003).
range: This species is widely distributed in the Indo-West Pacific, from the Persian Gulf to India and the Maldives, east to Myanmar, Malaysia, Indonesia, Brunei Darussalam, northern Australia and Papua New Guinea, and north to the South China Sea, the Philippines, the Gulf of Tonkin, China (Hainan), and Taiwan, Province of China (Randall 1995, Termvidchakorn 1999, Hensley 2001, Larson et al. 2013, Voronina et al. 2016, Yennawar et al. 2017, Amaoka 2019, Psomadakis et al. 2019). Although the type locality was reported as New Zealand (Gunther 1862), this is likely in error (Norman 1934, Randall 1995) and no modern works report specimens of B. novaezeelandiae from New Zealand (e.g., Munroe 2015, Roberts et al. 2017, McMillan et al. 2019). Its depth range is 18-95 m (Randall 1995, Hensley 2001, Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003).
useTrade: This species is not commercially targeted, but is taken mainly as bycatch in demersal trawls. It has minor commercial value (Yennawar et al. 2017). When taken, it is marketed fresh, where it is mainly used in the production of fish meal or feeds for aquaculture operations. It is also a component of the discarded bycatch of some trawl fisheries (Carpenter et al. 1997, Hensley 2001), including the Northern Prawn Fishery conducted along the northern coast of Australia (Griffiths et al. 2006). It is apparently rare in the landed bycatch of demersal fisheries conducted off southern Taiwan (Amaoka 2019).
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place. Its distribution may coincide with a number of marine protected areas including the El Nido Managed Natural Resource and Protected Area. Further research is needed on population size and trend, and extent of its take in demersal fisheries, both as landed catch and contribution to the bycatch.

rationale: The taxonomic status of the nominal species Cynoglossus arel and C. macrolepidotus remain uncertain. Cynoglossus macrolepidotus may be a junior synonym of C. arel; however, other authors consider both to be valid species. Based on available reports, both nominal species are widely distributed in the Indo-West Pacific. One, or both, nominal species, constitute a component of bycatch in demersal trawl fisheries; in India, reported landings of C. macrolepidotus are much higher compared to those reported as C. arel. However, disentangling reported information for C. arel and C. macrolepidotus from other areas is not currently possible. In most cases, these nominal species are not distinguished in the fishery catches. Therefore, this species is listed as Data Deficient. Taxonomic work is needed to clarify the status of these two nominal species.
habitat: This demersal, marine species inhabits the soft substrates of estuaries and those on continental shelves (Menon 1984, Munroe 2001, Monikh et al. 2012, Ghaffari et al. 2015). Its diet consists of benthic invertebrates (Munroe 2001, Hussain et al. 2007, Lakshmi 2010); juveniles primarily consume small crustaceans (such as amphipods and copepods) and bivalves (Atabak 2011, Baeck et al. 2011). Its mucus has been shown to have antimicrobial properties that help prevent infections from pathogens (i.e., bacteria, fungi and parasites) (Bragadeeswaran et al. 2011). It is a short-lived species with a sex ratio of 1:1 and a longevity of 3 to 5 years (Reichert 1998, M. Al-Hussaini pers. comm. 2014). In the Persian Gulf, its spawning season is from February to June, with activity peaking in February or March (Ghaffari et al. 2015). The maximum recorded total length (TL) is 38 cm (Ramanathan and Natarajan 1979, Munroe 2001). Size at first maturity for females has been estimated at 20.3 cm TL (Ghaffari et al. 2015).
threats: The population-level impacts of its take in demersal trawl fisheries is unknown.
population: This species appears to be the most common tonguesole in the Persian Gulf (Randall 1995). It is considered rare in some parts of its range (e.g., the Ponnani estuary, Kerala, India: Bijukumar and Sushama 2000; Wadge Bank, South India: Karuppasamy 2016).
range: Cynoglossus arel is widely distributed in the Indo-West Pacific from the Red Sea, east to Indonesia, and north to the Philippines, Taiwan, and southern Japan (Munroe 2001, Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003, Ramesh et al. 2008, Al-Jufaili et al. 2010, Rajan et al. 2013, T. Munroe pers. comm. 2014). It is found at depths ranging from 9 to 223 metres (Munroe 2001, Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003).
useTrade: This species is caught with bottom trawls and is marketed fresh, frozen and dried salted (Menon 1984, Munroe 2001, Brinda et al. 2010, Monikh et al. 2012, Ghaffari et al. 2015). It also occurs as bycatch in shrimp trawl fisheries (Paighambari and Daliri 2012, Ghaffari et al. 2015). This species contributes to fisheries of Maharashtra (CMFRI 2015) and Digha (CMFRI 2017), India, where it is considered underexploited.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place; however, its range overlaps with a number of marine protected areas such as the Gulf of Mannar Marine National Park, India (Nammalwar et al. 2013, IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2018). Due to overexploitation of demersal fishery resources, many countries of the Persian Gulf have implemented conservation measures such as fishing licenses, regulation of fishing gear and capture size, closing fishing areas, restricting fishing season, and banning fish trawling; however, enforcement and management may be lacking (Siddeek et al. 1999).

rationale: This relatively small-sized flatfish is widely distributed in nearshore waters of the Indo-West Pacific. No directed fishery exists for this species, but it is a component of bycatch in demersal trawl fisheries and is taken by subsistence fishers. When taken, it is marketed, together with other small-sized soleids. No data are available to determine population trends for this species at this time. However, given its wide distribution, it is listed as Least Concern. Recommendations to improve future assessments for this species include obtaining better information regarding the distribution, population size and trend, habitat specificity, basic life history features, and exploitation rates.
habitat: This demersal, marine species inhabits soft substrates of nearshore, coastal areas, including intertidal mudflats, rivers, estuaries, and seagrass beds (Munroe 2001, Satapoomin 2011, Lee et al. 2013, Mukherjee et al. 2013). Its diet consists mainly of benthic invertebrates, especially small crustaceans (Menon 1984, Lakshmi 2010). The maximum recorded total length is 36 cm (Hussain et al. 2010).
threats: Population-level effects of exploitation are unquantified. As it is a coastal and estuarine species, anthropogenic activities in these sensitive areas may negatively affect this species; however, at this time, the degree to which the species relies on estuaries is unknown.
population: Population information is limited. Punpoka (1964) considered it to be a very common species, frequently seen in the markets of Thailand. It is considered rare within the Indian Sundarbans and very rare along the southern Kerala coast of India (Pal et al. 2014, Baiju et al. 2016). It is uncommon along the coasts of southeast India (Biswas et al. 2014).
range: This species is widely distributed in the Indo-West Pacific, from Kenya, Mauritius, the Seychelles, southeastern Iran, India, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Viet Nam, and Taiwan, Province of China (Munro 1955; Punpoka 1964; Munroe 2000, 2001; Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003; Vachon et al. 2007; Ho et al. 2009; Al-Jufalili et al. 2010; Satapoomin 2011; Munga et al. 2014; Joshi et al. 2016; Voronina et al. 2016; Psomadakis et al. 2019). Accounts from the Red Sea are based on an erroneous map distribution (Golani and Bogorodsky 2010). Although Menon (1984) reports that it is found throughout the Persian Gulf, its presence in the Gulf requires further verification. It is found at depths ranging from 20 to 60 m (Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003).
useTrade: It is caught with shore seines and bottom trawls. It is marketed fresh, frozen and dried salted (Menon 1984, Munroe 2001), and may be used for animal feeds (T.A. Munroe pers. comm.). It occurs as bycatch in shrimp trawl fisheries; however, it is not targeted and is not considered particularly valuable when marketed.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place; however, its range overlaps with a number of marine protected areas such as the Gulf of Mannar Marine National Park, India (Nammalwar et al. 2013, Joshi et al. 2016, IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2018).

rationale: This deepwater, demersal species is found in the Western Central Atlantic. It is not targeted but taken as by-catch in demersal trawl fisheries. However, it is unlikely to be rapidly declining as it occurs below the depth at which most commercial fisheries operate in this region. Habitat degradation is unlikely to be a concern at this depth range. Ancylopsetta cycloidea has been assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This demersal species inhabits the sand and mud substrates on the continental shelf (Munroe 2002, Reyes et al. 2005, Robertson and Van Tassell 2015). The maximum total length is 25 cm (Munroe 2002, Robertson and Van Tassell 2015).
threats: Ancylopsetta cycloidea is caught as by-catch by both shrimp and finfish fisheries, however due to the deepwater nature of this species and the maximum depth to which these fisheries trawl (100 m), it is unlikely to be harvested in significant quantities (A. Acero and J.G. Nielsen pers. comm. 2009).
population: Population data are limited. It is known from its holotype and at least 50 specimens collected in the Caribbean Sea and western Atlantic Ocean (Tyler 1959, Gutherz 1966).
range: This species is distributed in the Caribbean Sea and western Atlantic Ocean: from Anguilla to Tobago and from Honduras to Suriname and French Guiana (Munroe 2002, R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014, Robertson and Van Tassell 2015) and may also occur in Brazil (Munroe 2002). Its depth range is 70-304 metres (Munroe 2002, Paramo et al. 2012, Robertson and Van Tassell 2015).
useTrade: There is no directed fishery for this species (A. Acero pers. comm. 2009). It is caught as bycatch in the shrimp and finfish trawl fisheries and marketed fresh (Munroe 2002).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This species is listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is likely to be within 100 km², it is known from a single site and threat-defined location, and there is ongoing decline of its forest habitat in Alagoas, Brazil.
habitat: The species is known from the mountainous region within the Mata da Bananeira. This region is characterized by rugged terrain with elevations between 200-600 m asl, and is largely covered by tropical rainforest. Individuals have been recorded in close proximity to a forest stream approximately 1-1.5 m above the ground (Cruz et al. 2011). It is an arboreal species that occupies forests and bromeliads with water, and reproduces by aquatic larval development (M.G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014). It is not considered to tolerate habitat disturbance, as it appears to be dependent on water and dense canopy cover (M.G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014).
threats: The Mata da Bananeira, where this species is recorded, occurs within the “Pernambuco Center of Endemism”. The high level of endemism within this region is threatened by human activities, particularly deforestation for the development of sugar-cane plantations, subsistence farming and pastures for cattle (Cruz et al. 2011). In addition, there is also ongoing illegal removal of vegetation (M.G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014).
population: It is considered to be a rare species (M.G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014). Given its apparently strong association with forest cover, its population is thought potentially to be in decline, as the forest where it occurs is itself subject to decline (M. G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014).
range: This species is known from a single locality and threat-defined location (at 509 m asl) in Fazenda Bananeira, Mata da Bananeira, Municipality of Murici, State of Alagoas, northeastern Brazil (Cruz et al. 2011). Although it has not been searched for outside of the type locality, the species is thought to potentially be range-restricted, since the area where it is found has features that are rare in the state of Alagoas (an elevational range between 400-600 m asl, forest with dense canopy cover, water springs and high relative humidity; M. G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014). Although its extent of occurrence (EOO) has not been quantified, it is not considered to be greater than 100 km².
useTrade: There is no indication that this species is utilized.
conservationActions: It occurs within a 61 km² conservation unit (Estação Ecologica (ESEC) de Murici, Cruz et al. 2011). This conservation unit is protected, with activities including patrols and fire prevention; however, the surroundings are under constant pressure from sugar cane plantations and cattle ranching (M.G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014). The conservation unit has a management plan (M.G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014). More information is needed on its distribution and population status.

rationale: Listed as Endangered given that its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 721 km², it is known from only two threat-defined locations, it is considered to be severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline of its forest habitat in Northeastern Brazil.
habitat: It is known from the Mata Atlântica Biome (De Lima et al. 2011). It is an arboreal species found in forests, and within these, in water-bearing bromeliads (M.G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014). It is not considered to tolerate habitat degradation, as it appears to need both water and forest cover (M.G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014). It breeds via aquatic larval development (M. G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014).
threats: The areas where the species is known to occur are under considerable pressure due to urban development (residential neighbourhoods) and agricultural activities (sugar cane plantations) (M.G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014).
population: It is considered to be a common species (M.G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014). However, given that it is strongly associated to forest habitats, it could be possible that the population may be in decline due to habitat loss and forest fragmentation (M.G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014). It is considered to be severely fragmented given the enormous distance between the two known sites, that the species is a forest specialist and that it is considered to have limited dispersal capabilities (M.G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014).
range: This species is known from two sites and threat-defined locations: one within the Área de Proteção Ambiental do Catolé e Fernão Velho, Municipality of Maceió, State of Alagoas, (De Lima et al. 2011), and a second site in Distrito de Chã de Cruz, municipality of Paudalho, State of Pernambuco, northeastern Brazil (M. G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014). Its elevational range is from 0-100 m asl (M. G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014). It is expected to occur more widely in the states of Alagoas and Pernambuco, although it is considered to be restricted to suitable forest habitat (M. G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 721 km².
useTrade: There is no indication that this species is utilized.
conservationActions: It occurs within a conservation unit of 54 km² (APA do Catolé e Fernão Velho, De Lima et al. 2011). However, this conservation unit is surrounded by residential development, sugar cane plantations and cattle farming ranches, and in some areas there is evidence of  illegal poaching, fires and deforestation (M.G. De Lima pers. comm. October 2014), so increased enforcement of the unit is needed. More information is needed on this species' distribution and population status.

rationale: This western central Atlantic species is known from Isla de Providencia (Colombia) and Venezuela. It has no major threats. This species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is demersal.
threats: There are no known threats for this species.
population: There is no species specific population information available.
range: This western central Atlantic species is known in the Caribbean Sea from Isla de Providencia (Colombia) and along the coast from the Gulf of Morrosquillo, Colombia to Carupano, Venezuela (Acero 1984).
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because it is known only from the type locality and there are no data on population size and trends, ecology, and the threats that may be affecting it.
habitat: It has been reported from roadside areas on stone and clay walls in modified forest habitats at an elevation of about 1,200-1,300 m (Darevsky et al.1998).
threats: The threats to the species are not known. However, it has been collected in disturbed habitats in roadside areas.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is endemic to east Nepal where it is known only from a single locality in Ilam, Mechi (Darevsky et al. 1997, Kastle et al. 2013).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. It has not been recorded in protected areas. Research is needed to better determine its distribution, population size and trends and the threats that may be affecting it.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because it is known only from  the type locality and there are no data on population size and trends,  ecology, and the threats that may be affecting it.
habitat: The specimen of the species were collected on roadside on stone and clay walls along the mountain at an elevational range of 1,200 m to 1,300 m (Darevsky et al. 1997).
threats: The threats to the species are not known.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is endemic to Nepal where it is known only from the type locality in a road between Ilam town and Pawakhola village, 1,200-1,300 m elevation, Ilam district Mechi Zone.
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. It has not  been recorded in protected areas. Research is needed to better  determine its distribution, population size and trends and the threats  that may be affecting it.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because it is known only from   the type locality and there are no data on population size and trends,   ecology, and the threats that may be affecting it.
habitat: It was recorded at an elevation of about 757 m asl (Kastle et al. 2013).  Only known from its original description, in a village between houses (Kastle et al. 2013).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is endemic to far western Nepal where it is known only from the type locality in Sakayal, a small village with a new police station, close to Dipayal, Doti District) (Kastle et al. 2013).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. It has not   been recorded in protected areas. Research is needed to better   determine its distribution, population size and trends and the threats   that may be affecting it.

rationale: Hippocampus pontohi is a coastal pygmy seahorse species that inhabits waters in the Indo-West Pacific from Indonesia to Fiji and from the Ryukyu Islands to southern Papua New Guinea. Their habitat includes hydroids, bryozoans, and algae, most notably of the genus Halimeda.  The species may be susceptible to Halimeda habitat loss as a result of ocean acidification, but is able to utilise other habitats. It is listed on CITES Appendix II. Therefore Hippocampus pontohi is listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Hippocampus pontohi is found among algae, bryozoans, and hydroid crops, especially the coralline algae Halimeda and hydroid Aglaephenia cupressina (Lourie and Kuiter 2008). Little is known about their feeding, but they likely have diets similar to other seahorses, which include small crustaceans such as caprellid, gammarid, and caridean shrimps and harpacticoid copepods (Woods 2002, Kendrick and Hyndes 2005, Kitsos et al. 2008). As is exhibited in other seahorses, they are ovoviviparous and the males brood the young in a pouch prior to giving live birth (Foster and Vincent 2004). 
 
This species is extremely small in size, with a height of 14 mm and a standard length of 17 mm (Lourie and Kuiter 2008).
 
They are commonly found in pairs and are relatively active. Two of the specimens collected were pregnant and each contained 11 embryos (Lourie and Kuiter 2008).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown. Their most commonly observed substrate, Halimeda algae, which exhibits calcium carbonate defensive and structural tissues, is likely susceptible to declines because of ocean acidification (Robbins et al. 2009, Price et al. 2011, Sinutok et al. 2012). Further research is needed in order to determine how much H. pontohi depends on Halimeda, and how ocean acidification is affecting the Halimeda populaiton.
population: To date there have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for Hippocampus pontohi. Further research is needed in order to determine population size and trends in abundance for this species.
range: Hippocampus pontohi inhabits waters in the Indo-West Pacific from southern Sumatra to Fiji and from the Ryukyu Islands to southern Indonesia and Papua New Guinea, including the Solomon Islands (Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Natural History 2010, Lourie et al. 2016).
useTrade: There are no records of trade in Hippocampus pontohi. Although the species is likely attractive for the aquarium trade, they are notoriously hard to find and do not do well in captivity.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Hippocampus pontohi. The species is found in several protected areas, including Bunaken National Park, Indonesia. It is listed on CITES Appendix II. Further research is needed in order to determine how much H. pontohi depends on Halimeda, and how ocean acidification is affecting Halimeda populations.

rationale: This species is only known from coastal Tanzania, Zanzibar and Mozambique. Records from Madagascar and Kenya need to be confirmed. There is no population information, and it is found in very shallow nearshore waters and tidepools. It is listed as Least Concern. More information on this species population and habitat is needed, as coastal development and pollution likely poses a threat to this species at least in urban areas.
habitat: Although there is very little to no habitat and ecology information available for A. simplex, its genus Acentrogobius inhabit mangroves, estuaries, coastal bays and at times fresh water (Allen et al. 2015). Despite the fact that Kenyan accounts of A. simplex need to be confirmed, this species was suspected of utilizing crab burrows as refuge in a Kenyan mangrove swamp (Berti et al. 2008). The maximum recorded length for this species is 10 cm TL (Maugé 1986).
threats: Coastal pollution and urban development likely threatens this species habitat around Dar es Salaam (Machiwa 2010).
population: There is little to no population data for A. simplex.
range: Acentrogobius simplex is a Western Indian Ocean species that is known from Mozambique (Roger Bills, photo pers. comm. to Helen Larson 2017), Tanzania, Zanzibar, and Madagascar (Fourmanoir and Maugé 1962, Maugé 1986, Okeyo 1998). Accounts from Kenya need confirmation (Seegers et al. 2003). It can be found in tidepools, at depths of less than 1 meter (Smith 1959).
useTrade: There is no use and trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures for A. simplex; however, its range overlaps with a number of marine protected areas (IUCN and UNEP 2014).

rationale: Hippocampus paradoxus is a poorly known seahorse species that is endemic to southwestern Australia. It has been recorded from areas on the continental shelf at depths of 94 -110 m that consist of sand and sponges and bryozoans. Little is known about population size and trends in abundance or threats. Therefore this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The type locality that this species was described from is on the shelf benthos, and is characterised by sand interspersed with sponges and bryozoans. This includes members of the genus Adeona, the family Catenicellidae, and lace corals of the family Phidoloporidae (Foster and Gomon 2010). Little is known about feeding, but other seahorses tend to consume crustaceans such as gammarid and caridean shrimps, mysids, amphipods, and copepods (Woods 2002, Kitsos et al. 2008). Their reproductive biology is also unknown, but seahorses in general are ovoviviparous and males brood the young in a pouch prior to giving live birth (Foster and Vincent 2004).
threats: The threats to this species and its habitat are unknown. It may be caught as bycatch, but levels of offtake are unknown.
population: There have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for Hippocampus paradoxus. Further research is needed in order to determine population size and trends in abundance for this species.
range: Hippocampus paradoxus is known only from the type locality southwest of Esperance, Western Australia, where it was taken from a depth of 102 m (Foster and Gomon 2010).
useTrade: This species has not been recorded in trade, but other seahorses are traded heavily globally for traditional medicines, curios, and aquarium use (Vincent et al. 2011).  Some illegal trade occurs in Australia, but levels are low compared to other regions (Martin-Smith and Vincent 2006). This species may be involved but likely at low levels.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Hippocampus paradoxus. It is listed along with all other seahorses on CITES Appendix II, where trade by the parties must be shown to be sustainable if it is suspected otherwise (Vincent et al. 2013). The species is also protected along with all other syngnathids by the Australian Environmental Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act (1999). It's unclear at this time whether the species occurs in any protected areas.

rationale: Solegnathus robustus is a marine outer shelf pipehorse species that is endemic to southern Australia. The species may be particularly susceptible to being caught as bycatch and traded for traditional medicines, as are other members of the genus, but this has not been quantified. Further research is needed in order to determine this species' habitat, population size, trends in abundance, and levels of bycatch. The species is protected from targeted fisheries throughout its range, and there are measures in place to ensure bycatch levels are not of concern. There are no other known threats. Therefore Solegnathus robustus is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Solegnathus robustus is a temperate-water pipehorse, which occurs in benthic habitats of the continental shelf (Paxton et al. 1989) and has been recorded in depths of 42-68 m (Dawson 1985). The diet is unknown but like other species in the family, S. robustus probably feeds on small crustaceans (Pogonoski et al. 2002, Kendrick and Hyndes 2005).  The species is ovoviviparous and males brood the embryos beneath their tail prior to giving live birth (Breder and Rosen 1966, Dawson 1985). Solegnathus robustus attains a total length of at least 350 mm, and the smallest examined brooding male was 314 mm total length (Dawson 1985).
threats: Commercial trawl fishing in the Great Australian Bight has been suggested as a potential threat to this species, as individuals could be captured as bycatch (Pogonoski et al. 2002). However, no information exists on verified threats to the species. There are management measures in place to minimize bycatch with EPBC Act listed species, but none are specifically in place for this species currently (see Conservation section).
population: To date there have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for Solegnathus robustus. Further research is needed in order to determine population size and trends in abundance for this species.
range: Solegnathus robustus is endemic to the coastal waters of southern Australia, including the South Australian Bight and the Spencer Gulf westwards to Flinders Island in Tasmania (Dawson 1982, 1985; GBIF 2016).
useTrade: Although this species has not been recorded in trade, syngnathids in general and pipehorses in particular are widely used for traditional medicine, and other members of this genus are traded heavily in Australia for export to Hong Kong and other East and Southeast Asian countries (Martin-Smith et al. 2003, Martin-Smith and Vincent 2006).
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Solegnathus robustus. Along with all syngnathids, the species is subject to the export controls of the Commonwealth Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 from 1 January 1998 (Pogonoski et al. 2002). All syngnathids and solenostomids were also listed as marine species under section 248 of the EPBC Act 1999 (Pogonoski et al. 2002). It occurs in the South Australia Bight Marine Park. The species is not mentioned in any international legislation or trade regulations.

There is a Great Australian Bight Trawl Sector Bycatch and Discarding Workplan in place (Australian Fisheries Management Authority 2014) that aims to reduce interactions with species listed under the EPBC Act. There are no measures in place specifically for this species.

rationale: Trimma caudipunctatum is recorded from two specimens from Japan and Palau and a small number of observations. There is no information available regarding this species' population size or trends, its habitat, ecology or biology. The species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is no information available on this species' habitat preferences or ecology. Other closely related dwarfgobies are found on and among coral reefs (Allen and Erdamnn 2012) and are usually secretive and hide in caves, cracks and crevices of reefs (Larson and Murdy 2001). Its maximum recorded length is 2.1 cm SL (Suzuki and Senou 2009).
threats: No major threats are known to this species.
population: Population data are limited for T. caudipunctatum. It is known from two specimens and a number of observations.
range: Trimma caudipunctatum is distributed in the Western Pacific and is known from Japan (Ryukyu Islands) and Palau at depths between 40 an 70 m (Suzuki and Senou 2009).
useTrade: Trimma caudipunctatum is not known to be commercially utilised.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures for T. caudipunctatum; however, its range overlaps with a number of marine protected areas (IUCN and UNEP 2014).

rationale: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic Ocean  and south along the Central American coasts. This species is widely distributed but not common within its shallow coastal waters. This species is not exploited within its range. There are no known major threats and no species-specific conservation measures, therefore it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Batrachoides gilberti occurs in shallow coastal waters and also enters freshwaters. It feeds on xanthid and portunid crabs, shrimps, gastropods, and small fishes. Maximum size recorded is 23 cm standard length (SL) (Collette 2002). Males ripen by 16 cm SL; females by 18 cm SL. A 19 cm female from Panama had 398 eggs (4.4 to 5.3 mm in diameter) (Collette and Russo 1981).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This species is considered common, but not abundant (B. Collette pers. comm. 2012).
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic Ocean along the Central American coast from Chetumal, Mexico to the Canal Zone in Panama (Collette and Russo 1981, Greenfield et al. 2008). Although occurring in Belize, this species is restricted to the mainland, often entering fresh water, and not reaching the barrier reef or atolls where Sanopus and Vladichthys occur (Greenfield and Thomerson 1997). Records from the Gulf of Mexico are invalid (B. Collette pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: This species is not exploited.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 243 km<sup>2</sup>, its population considered to be severely fragmented, a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat in northern Peru, and a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals due to illegal collection for the pet trade.
habitat: This species occurs in dry, primary and secondary rocky premontane forests (Brown et al. 2008), characterized by an open canopy and rocky substrates (J.L. Brown and E. Twomey pers. comm. July 2011). It is a diurnal, terrestrial species, and breeding takes place in the humid leaf litter, with clutch sizes ranging from 4–9 eggs, and tadpoles are later transported into tree holes and phytotelm (water-holding plants) axils with small water pools, where they complete metamorphosis (Brown et al. 2008). Captive breeding efforts suggest that when conditions are adequate females may lay multiple clutches a year (Brown et al. 2008). This frog does not appear to be tolerant to habitat disturbance associated to agricultural activities (J.L. Brown and E. Twomey pers. comm. July 2011).
threats: In addition to illegal trade, this frog is threatened by extensive habitat loss given that much if its habitat is near human settlements, and the constant encroachment by small-holder farmers and agro-industry seeking to expand their farmland is causing rapid deforestation, thus comprising a major threat to this species (Brown et al. 2008, E. Twomey pers. comm. April 2013). Around the type locality of Sauce and other known localities (e.g. Chazuta) deforestation remains extensive and two of the sites where this species was found are on the verge of being destroyed (E. Twomey pers. comm. April 2013).
population: In the last three decades the subpopulation in the locality of Chazuta, where smuggling operations have typically taken place, appears to have experienced a dramatic decline. Subpopulations in other areas that seem to be overlooked by illegal collectors appear to flourishing (Brown et al. 2008). The global population is considered to be severely fragmented given that its habitat is in fragmented patches, more than half of the individuals are in small and isolated patches, and the species' biology is not conducive to dispersal in between habitat patches (J.L. Brown pers. comm. July 2011, E. Twomey, pers. comm. April 2013). Approximately 20 individuals have been observed in the past few years (E. Twomey pers. comm. April 2013).
range: This frog is known from nine geographic localities in the central Huallaga Canyon and surrounding semiarid valleys, including both sides of the Río Huallaga, into the southernmost edge of the Cordillera Escalera and to the northwestern edge of the Cordillera Azul, in the region of San Martín, northern Peru (Brown et al. 2008, J.L. Brown et al. 2011, Brown pers. comm. July 2011, E. Twomey pers. comm. April 2013). It can be found from 180–700 m asl (J.L. Brown and E. Twomey pers. comm. July 2011). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 243 km2. It has a spotty distribution within this realm, most of which is comprised of unsuitable habitat (Brown et al. 2008, J.L. Brown and E. Twomey pers. comm. July 2011).
useTrade: Brown et al. (2008) indicate that illegal collecting for the pet trade may have had localized impacts in certain areas. The species began to be legally exported in 2001, but almost all frogs currently in the pet trade are of illegal origin, including captive-bred frogs originated from smuggled ancestors (J.L. Brown and E. Twomey pers. comm. July 2011, J.L. Brown pers. comm. August 2011).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is not known to occur in any protected areas, although given its proximity to Cordillera Escalera Regional Conservation Area and Cordillera Azul National Park it could potentially occur there. It is included in Appendix II of CITES. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru according to the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Conservation Needed
Given the degree of ongoing habitat loss occurring throughout its range, habitat protection is urgently needed. Legislation and enforcement of legislation is needed to address the issue of illegal trade.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' population status and level of trade.

rationale: This species is known from the island of New Providence, Bahamas, but has been driven to extinction by human disturbance. A specimen was taken in 1877 and it was probably Extinct soon afterwards: subsequent collectors found no trace of it.
habitat: Nothing is known, though it was likely to have been typical of the genus.
threats: The cause of its extinction is unknown, presumably owing to some kind of human disturbance (Olson and Hilgartner 1982).
population: None remain.
range: Chlorostilbon bracei is known only from the type, described in 1877 by Lawrence, from New Providence, Bahamas (Olson and Hilgartner 1982), although fossil hummingbird bones found on the island (Graves and Olson 1987) are probably also referable to this species (Olson and Hilgartner 1982).

rationale: This species was known from the Society Islands, French Polynesia, but has been driven Extinct by cat and rat predation. It was last recorded on Mehetia in the 1930s.
habitat: Nothing is known.
threats: It was flightless, and its extinction was presumably caused by introduced cats and rats (Bruner 1972).
population: None remain.
range: Hypotaenidia pacificus is known only from Forster's painting from Tahiti, French Polynesia, in the British Museum (Knox and Walters 1994), from Cook's second voyage in 1773 (Stattersfield et al. 1994), although there were reports from Tahiti until 1844, and from the nearby Mehetia until the 1930s (Bruner 1972).

rationale: This species was known from Lord Howe Island, Australia, but has not been definitely recorded since 1790 and was Extinct by the time the island was settled in 1834. Hunting was the major cause of its decline.
habitat: Nothing is known, it may have inhabited forest or marshland.
threats: It was hunted to extinction by whalers and sailors.
population: None remain.
range: Porphyrio albus is known from two skins in Liverpool and Vienna (Taylor and van Perlo 1998), several paintings, and some subfossil bones from Lord Howe Island, Australia (Marchant and Higgins 1993). Although not uncommon when discovered in 1790, the species was rapidly hunted to extinction; it had probably already vanished by the time the island was colonised in 1834 (Hindwood 1940).

rationale: This species was endemic to the island of Rodrigues, Mauritius, but is now Extinct, probably due to a combination of hunting, habitat loss and the action of invasive species. The last records date from 1726, and the species was not found on a visit in 1761.
habitat: Nothing is known, although a travellers account of a bird which fed on the contents of the eggs of seabirds and turtles may refer to this species.
threats: The reason for this species's extinction is unknown (Cheke 1987), but hunting, habitat destruction and the depredations of introduced mammals must surely all have contributed.
population: No extant population remains.
range: Necropsar rodericanus is known only from bones from Rodrigues, Mauritius (Cowles 1987), which are presumably referable to the birds "Testudophaga bicolor" (Rothschild 1907) described by Tafforet from Ile du Mât in 1726. These constitute the last records and no birds were seen by Pingré in 1961 (Cheke 1987).

rationale: This taxon is known from one specimen, probably from Jamaica, taken in 1860. It is now Extinct, likely due to deforestation or predation by introduced species.
habitat: Nothing is known, though it is likely to be typical for the genus.
threats: Reasons for its extinction are difficult to infer, though the extinction of its preferred food plants or habitat through deforestation, or predation by introduced mammals may be responsible.
population: No extant population remains.
range: Chlorostilbon elegans, described from a single specimen (in Tring) by Gould in 1860, was recently shown by Weller (1999) to be a valid species, presumably extinct, and possibly (by inference) from Jamaica or the north Bahamas.

rationale: This species was known from St Helena, but is now Extinct. It was presumably driven to extinction by hunting soon after the island was discovered in 1502.
habitat: Nothing is known.
threats: It was large and flightless, and therefore probably hunted to extinction by humans and introduced predators.
population: No extant population remains.
range: Atlantisia podarces was described from fossils by Wetmore (1963) as a St Helena (to UK) endemic genus, Aphanocrex, but re-assigned to Atlantisia by Olson (1973). It presumably became extinct soon after the discovery of the island in 1502.

rationale: This species was known from Tahiti, but presumably went Extinct soon after it was last described in 1784. Introduced predators are likely to have been responsible.
habitat: Nothing is known.
threats: Introduced predators are likely to have led to its demise.
population: No extant population remains.
range: Zapornia nigra is known from two illustrations, one by Forster from Tahiti, French Polynesia, from Cook's second voyage (1772-1775), and the other by Miller from 1784, and by subsequent descriptions by Latham and Gmelin. It presumably became extinct soon after (Walters 1988).

rationale: This species was known from St Helena, but is now Extinct. It is likely to have been driven to extinction by introduced predators soon after the island was discovered in 1502.
habitat: Nothing is known.
threats: It was driven to extinction by introduced predators.
population: No extant population remains.
range: Zapornia astrictocarpus is only known from fossils from St Helena (to UK) (Olson 1975b). It is likely to have become extinct soon after the island was discovered in 1502 (Olson 1973).

rationale: This species has an very large range, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the range size criterion (Extent of Occurrence <20,000 km2 combined with a declining or fluctuating range size, habitat extent/quality, or population size and a small number of locations or severe fragmentation). The population trend appears to be stable, and hence the species does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population trend criterion (>30% decline over ten years or three generations). The population size has not been quantified, but it is not believed to approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population size criterion (<10,000 mature individuals with a continuing decline estimated to be >10% in ten years or three generations, or with a specified population structure). For these reasons the species is evaluated as Least Concern.
population: There is little information on population size (del Hoyo et al. 1996).

rationale: It is listed as Data Deficient, because there is still little information on populations and habitat requirements. Additional studies are needed to understand more precisely the respective characteristics of P. vexillaris and P. obesus in terms of distribution, ecology and general biology.
habitat: This species is found in areas with consolidated sands with sparse, halophil vegetation. It is associated with Chenopodiaceae.
threats: There are no major threats to this species, however, climatic variability and land use changes have caused considerable changes in vegetation in the region (Hanafi and Jauffret 2008).
population: The abundance of this species is unknown. It is often confused with Psammomys obesus.
range: This North African species ranges from northeastern Algeria, through central Tunisia to northwestern Libya.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place; it is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the taxonomy, distribution, abundance, reproduction and ecology of this species.

rationale: This species is widely distributed and common where it occurs in the open ocean associated with Physalia physali and Sargassum. There are no known major threats, therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is oceanic and juveniles are associated with the Portuguese man-of-war (Physalia physalis) (Jenkins 1983). Juveniles are found at the surface amidst Sargassum. The maximum length is 40 cm (Haedrich 2002).
threats: There are no known threats to this species.
population: Nomeus gronovii is common in the western Atlantic (Haedrich 2002), but rare in the eastern Atlantic.
range: Nomeus gronovii is circumglobal in temperate and tropical waters in all oceans (Haedrich 2002). In the western Atlantic it is known from Newfoundland (Canada) south along the U.S., Bermuda, the Bahamas, throughout the Gulf of Mexico and Caribbean Sea, and along South America to southern Brazil. In the eastern Atlantic it has been recorded from Morocco to Senegal and Sao Tome Island. In the Indo-Pacific it is known from along East Africa, India, Indonesia, the Philippines, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, and the Hawaiian Islands. In the eastern Pacific it is known from southern California (USA) to Peru. This is a typically surface-dwelling species found offshore to 1000 m depth (May and Maxwell 1986, Mundy 2005).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened because, although it is relatively abundant within its small range, its Extent of Occurrence is less than 5,000 km2, and the extent and quality of its habitat are possibly declining, thus making the species close to qualifying for Endangered.
habitat: Populations are usually encountered in moderately arid slopes of gorges and rocky outcrops. It can be found among overgrown wooded ruins, and on stone walls and fences. It is a parthenogenic species. The females lay clutches of two to five eggs (most often four eggs).
threats: This species is threatened by increasing urbanization and road construction, with settlement of people around the remaining fragmented populations. There appears to be increasing competition with sympatric species.
population: This is a rare species.
range: This species is endemic to the Caucasus, where it has been recorded from eight locations in northern Armenia and southern Georgia. It is comparatively widely distributed the foothills of the Kura River valley. Populations are patchily distributed and isolated. The species has been recorded from 900 to 1,700m asl.
conservationActions: It is not known if this species is present within any protected areas. Additional studies are needed into the distribution and natural history of this species. There is a need to regularly monitor population and record and reductions in the numbers of animals.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened because this species is probably in significant decline (but probably at a rate of less than 30% over ten years) because of widespread habitat loss and fragmentation of remaining populations through much of its range, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable.
habitat: This species is typically associated with damp areas in forested montane habitats; animals are occasionally recorded from rocks or walls. The subspecies D. d. silvatica populates mesophilous flood plains, beech and fir tree forests usually from 600m up to 1,300m, and occasionally up to 1,600m asl. D. d. boehmei inhabits forests and subalpine meadows from sea level (in Ajaria) to 1,800m asl (Trialetsky ridge). It is absent from sea shore xerophilous habitats. The female lays a clutch of between four and eight eggs (Baran and Atatur 1998).
threats: Ongoing habitat loss through deforestation is considered to be a major threat to this species. The montane habitats of this species are believed to be increasingly threatened by climate change.
population: It is a locally common species in good habitat.
range: This species is found in the Caucasus region, where it has been recorded from Georgia, southern Russia, northeastern Turkey (Vilayets Ardahan, Artvin, Trabzon and Rize) and just into western Azerbaijan (Baran and Atatür, 1998). It is found up to 1,700m asl.
conservationActions: This species is found within the Caucasian State Biosphere Reserve and the Sochi State Natural National Park. There is a need to conserve suitable remaining areas of forest habitat for this species.

rationale: This species has a large population size and a wide distribution. No decline in population size has been detected, and there are no known widespread major threats, therefore is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Inhabits arid and semiarid grassland and scrubland between the upper limits of coniferous forest and the edge of snow line. Found in forest-steppe, steppe and mountain-steppe habitats associated with juniper and alpine meadows and rocky meadow outcrops.
threats: No available data.
population: No data are available at present.
range: Distributed in lowland dry rocky steppes from Tuva, through Mongolia (with the exception of western and north-eastern parts of the country) and N China.
conservationActions: Approximately 10% of the species’ range in Mongolia occurs within protected areas. In China and Russia listed as Least Concern. Conservation measures required. Further research is recommended.

rationale: This species has a large population size and a wide distribution. No decline in population size has been detected, and there are no known widespread major threats.
habitat: Inhabits steppe, forest and semi-desert habitats in Mongolia, associated with poa-wormwood and poa vegetation. Known to inhabit grasslands in China and and dry steppes and grasslands in Russia around the borders of the country. The density and height of vegetation influences habitat selection in this species, and they will favour short vegetation between 30 and 130 mm in height.  It has been shown that population growth rates are slower in areas of short grass where little food is available. However, if vegetation is too long, this can disrupts social interactions and predator detection, causing a lowered growth rate. This is a keystone species in the steppe ecosystem, aerating soil through burrowing and encouraging plant diversity. This diurnal species lives in dens with many entrances and separated chambers. Family den might be up to 30 m long. Feed on vegetative and underground parts of plants, and may hoard more than 10 kg of those per family.
threats: Considered a pest as population outbreaks of this species can compete with livestock for resources and spread disease. However, such outbreaks are more likely to occur in overgrazed areas, so they cause little additional environmental damage. Poisoning campaigns using Bromadiolone are being phased out because they have little effect on this species, but impact significantly on non-target species, e.g. livestock and humans. Underwent a major range expansion during the twentieth century, and experiences population fluctuations cycling over 9-11 years (Dawaa et al., 2005).
population: This species experiences cyclic population outbreaks every 3-14 years. The frequency of outbreaks varies regionally, for example, in eastern regions it occurs roughly every 4 yrs. In the last 50 years, 17 severe outbreaks have been recorded in Inner Mongolia (written in 2004), and the frequency of outbreaks has increased over the past 20 years compared to the previous 20 years, co-inciding with a 5 fold increase in livestock numbers. They are also prey for many carnivores including foxes, Pallas' cats and polecats, but predation pressure doesn't influence population size except during low density years.
range: Inhaits open landscapes (steppes, grasslands) on planes and mountains (up to 2000 m asl) in Russian Federation, NE China, and C and E Mongolia.
conservationActions: Legal Status: Approximately 4% of the species’ range in Mongolia occurs within protected areas.

rationale: A widespread species, not believed to be declining at a significant rate. Listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Inhabits mountain steppes and alpine meadows (up to 4000 m) spreading over gentle slopes.  Fewer live in stony mountain steppes strewn with boulders. Where the Gray Marmot lives in sympatry with the Siberian Marmot, the Gray Marmot occupies only tips of ridges characterized by alpine vegetation while the Siberian Marmot inhabits productive highland valleys. This species, like most marmots, is highly social, and lives in colonies with many burrows.  Summer and winter burrows are usually separate; winter burrows are deeper, while summer burrows are just as long, but not as deep; both types may hold 2-3 marmots, but in winter, up to 10. Marmots eat a wide variety of food plants, which vary with season. Early spring foods include Artemisia frigida; by late spring and early summer their diet consists mainly of grasses; and by late summer, herbaceous vegetation. Sometimes can eat animals.  Mating begins in early May and ends by the beginning of June.  Gestation lasts 40 days. Reproduces once a year, litter size is 2-6 pups.  Hibernation is initiated at different times in different places, from August to October, and appears influenced by local weather and food resources. Hibernation lasts 7-8 months.  Enemies include large raptors, wolves and other smaller predators such as foxes, steppe polecats, and Pallas’ cats.
threats: Unsustainable hunting for meat and for use in traditional medicines, although no international trade is believed to be occurring at present. Possible habitat degradation through grazing by increasing numbers of livestock.
population: Not abundant in northern parts of the range. In 1990, the Mongolian population size was estimated to be 600,000 (Demberel and Batbold, 1991).
range: Distributed in mountain (up to 4,000 m) steppes and alpine meadows in W Siberia, and Tuva (Russia), W Mongolia (Mongol Altai Mountain Range), E Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, and China (Xinjiang).
useTrade: It is hunted.
conservationActions: Hunting is permitted between August 11th and October 15th (MNE, 2005). Occurs within some protected areas (approximately 16% of the species’ range in Mongolia). Further research, legislation and education is recommended.

rationale: This species has a large population size and a wide distribution. No decline in population size has been detected, and there are no known widespread major threats. Listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Inhabits tundra, plains and mountain steppes and meadows. In the forest zone (including mountain forests) and semideserts it occupies open grassy areas. It reaches maximum density in cereal and grass steppes, and alpine and water meadows. Lives in groups, during periods of high population density may form colonies. Feeds on various wild and cultivated plants, tends to prefer legumes. Reproductive period lasts throughout the warmer months of the year; in tundra zones reproduction often starts under snow cover (in Karsk tundra in February-March). Has up to 5 litters per year in southern parts of the range, and up to 4 in mountains and northern areas. Litter size is usually up to 12 young. Considerable pest of crops in Siberia and Kazakhstan and pastures in Central Asia. A natural carrier of several diseases including encephalitis, plague,and rabbit fever.
threats: There are no major threats to the species.
population: Populations undergo fluctuations in density; in mountainous areas populations are patchy and density varies.
range: Distributed in several separated regions: in tundra and forest-tundra from White Sea to Kolyma River; in Alaska peninsula; in steppes of Kazakhstan, Kyrgizia, SW Siberia, Yakutia, Mongolia and Northern China. It occurs at altitudes of up to 4,000 m.
conservationActions: The species occurs in several protected areas.

rationale: A widespread species with no known major threats. Listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Occupies densely vegetated mountain foothills and riverbanks.  Especially active in early morning and late evening.  Digs burrows in dense vegetation, leaving obvious heaps of discarded soil around the entrance to its burrow with mounds 50-100 cm across and 15-20 cm high.  The passage to the burrow is only 20-30 cm long and leads directly to a round, 35 cm diameter nest chamber that is about 25 cm high.  They construct special food storage chambers, which they fill with roots and bulbs before winter. Feeds on grass vegetation. Reproduction little known, females with seven and nine embryos have been reported.
threats: No available data, although habitat loss through human-caused and natural wildfires may constitute a threat (but probably not a major one).
population: No data are available at present.
range: Distributed in open forest and steppe habitats to east from Baikal Lake Basin (Russia), in NE Mongolia (Mountain Range and Ikh Hyangan Mountain Range), NE China and Amur River Basin.
conservationActions: Approximately 38% of the species’ range in Mongolia occurs within protected areas. In China listed as NE. In Russia common species. Conservation measures required. Further research is recommended.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: The species is only found in the vicinity of succulent shrubs, which are its main food source. It is a habitat generalist, found in rocky habitats, grasslands, semi-desert and desert so long as succulent shrubs are present. This mostly diurnal species is colonial and lives in burrow systems in open terrain of soil or sand. The causative agent for Leishmaniasis has been isolated from this species in Jordan (Amr 2000). The species is used in laboratory studies on diabetes (Qumsiyeh 1996).
threats: No major threats. The species is persecuted as a pest and is a reservoir for cutaneous leishmaniasis.
population: This species is common. At times, population explosions occur.
range: This species is found in North Africa from Mauritania and Western Sahara to Egypt, and east through Sinai Peninsula into Saudi Arabia, Israel, Jordan and Syria. It is unevenly distributed probably due to its dependence on succulent plants for moisture. It has been recorded from a harbour in Sudan, where it may have been accidentally introduced.
useTrade: This species is used for experimental medicine for diabetes and obesity research.
conservationActions: Found in many protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because it is very wide ranging, its population is thought to be stable and there are no major threats.
habitat:
It is found from alpine to Sonoran life zones. Inhabits mountains, cliffs, talus slopes, caves, and rock outcrops, both in forests and open deserts; also found in abandoned buildings and mine shafts. Young are born in nests within den built of sticks among rocks or in old building/mine shafts. Breeding peaks in spring. Gestation lasts about five weeks. Up to 2-three litters per year. Litter size is about 3-4. Births occur April-August in California. Young males disperse by 2.5 months, many females breed in natal area. Commonly one adult male with 1-3 adult females (Escherich 1981).

Most individuals occupy separate dens. Male may exclude other males from small rock outcrop inhabited by multiple females (Escherich 1981). Home range size in Alberta averaged 6.1 ha for males, 3.6 ha for females, much larger than for other woodrat species.

These woodrats feed on a variety of vegetation; twigs, shoots, leaves, needles, fruit, and seeds. They may store food. They are active throughout the year. Primarily nocturnal but may be seen during the day.
threats: There are no major threats to this species.
population: This species is considered secure within its range (NatureServe). Density varies seasonally and annually, and seems to depend upon the density of suitable den sites. Average population density is about one per 20 acres (Banfield 1974).
range: Bushy-tailed woodrats occur from the Yukon Territory and Northwest Territories (Canada) south to Arizona and New Mexico and from California east to the Black Hills, South Dakota and the Badlands of the upper Missouri River drainage area of South Dakota and Nebraska in the United States.
conservationActions: This species is not of conservation concern and its range includes many protected areas.

rationale: The Peppered Goby (Pariah scotius) has been assessed as Least Concern.  There are no known major threats to this species.  It associates with sponges such as Spheciospongia vesparia, so it may be affected to some degree by habitat degradation, but this sponge is described as rather common in the western Caribbean (S. Zea pers. comm. 2009).  Habitat degradation is therefore not considered to be a major therat to the Peppered Goby at present.
habitat: The Peppered Goby is found inhabiting sponges, especially the sponge, Spheciospongia vesparia, which is typically found at a depth range of 15-60 m.
threats: It is unknown whether there are any major threat processes impacting the Peppered Goby.  Threats to sponges include water pollution from coastal development or boat traffic, and harvesting for the pharmaceutical industry.  At present, it is not known if these threats are having a significant impact on the Peppered Goby population. Given that this species associates with sponges such as Spheciospongia vesparia, it may be affected to some degree by habitat degradation, but this sponge is described as rather common in the western Caribbean (S. Zea pers. comm. 2009).
population: There is no population information available for the Peppered Gobi.
range: The Peppered Goby (Pariah scotius) has been found in the southern Bahamas and in Curaçao. Suitable habitat for this species (i.e., Spheciospongia vesparia) is common in the western Caribbean in reef lagoon areas.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for the Peppered Goby.  However, its distribution may coincide with marine protected areas.  Further research is needed to determine the abundance of this species and its rate of habitat loss.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence is expected to be less than 100 km<sup>2</sup>, its distribution is severely fragmented (no movement between known localities), and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its coastal dune forest habitat and area of occupancy
habitat: This is a small fossorial snake, it can be encountered in coastal sand dune forest, home gardens, and abandoned paddy fields (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
threats: This species is threatened by sand mining, and coastal development for tourism and urban development.
population: This species was described from a large type series of more than 20 specimens, all from one locality (Taylor 1947). Taylor (1947) suggests that the species is common but that "considerable effort is necessary to find it". New information confirms that this species is difficult to find, the population trend is not known (M. Wickramasinghe pers comm. 2019)
range: This truly restricted range species is known only from Sri Lanka, where it was formerly know only from '12 miles north of Trincomalee' (Taylor 1947), but more recently has been recorded from Gopalpuram (Nilavalley) and Navachcholei in Trincomalee District (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019). It occurs at about 2-5 m asl.
useTrade: There is not thought to be any use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is not present in any protected areas. Habitat protection is needed for the coastal dune forest where this species occurs. It does not seem viable to translocate populations of this species to areas away from the specific soil type needed. Additional research is needed into the taxonomy, distribution, habitat and ecology to this species.

rationale: This small-sized flatfish is widely distributed in the Indian Ocean, with unverified records from the Central Western Pacific. It is not targeted but may be taken in demersal trawl fisheries. Virtually no information is available regarding its population size and trends, basic life history features, and impacts of potential threats. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This small-sized, demersal, marine species inhabits sand and shell bottoms (Hensley 1986). Its diet likely consists of small benthic organisms. The maximum recorded standard length is 8 cm (Hensley and Amaoka 2001).
threats: Major threats are unknown.
population: No population data are available for this species.
range:
This species is reported from Somalia (based on ANSP 153417), India, and Indonesia (Alcock 1890, Hensley and Amaoka 2001, Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003, Barman et al. 2007, Venu 2013), and Hensley (1986) reported a juvenile specimen from South Africa. 

Hensley and Amaoka (2001) also reported this species from the South China Sea, but provide no documentation for this record, nor do they indicate a locality in the South China Sea on their distribution map for this species. Chen and Weng (1965) reported this species from Taiwan, but this record is erroneous as it is based on a misidentified specimen of Psettina iijimae according to Amaoka and Ho (2019). Perhaps this Taiwanese record is the basis for the distribution in the South China Sea reported by Hensley and Amaoka (2001). Cabanban et al. (1996, and again in 2010) listed this species for the Philippines based on R/V Albatross material collected in the early 1900s, but these records were not acknowledged by Hensley and Amaoka (2001). As such, the distribution of this species in the South China Sea remains uncertain. 

Manilo and Bogorodsky (2003) reported a depth range of 36-137 m, but this range includes depths for all specimens, including those for the Philippines. The depth range for specimens within the likely distribution of this species is 45.7-128 m (accessed via FishNet2 portal, March 2021).
useTrade: This species is not targeted, but may be taken as bycatch in demersal trawl fisheries.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place; however, its range may overlap with marine protected areas in parts of its range, such as the Gulf of Mannar Marine National Park, India (Nammalwar et al. 2013, IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2018).

rationale: This small-sized flatfish is known from relatively few specimens captured off KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, with other records (without vouchered specimens) from off East Africa. Limited information is available regarding population size or trends and potential threats for this species. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Cynoglossus acaudatus is a demersal, marine species inhabiting soft substrata on the continental shelf. Its diet consists of benthic invertebrates (Sommer et al. 1996). The maximum recorded total length for this species is 14 cm (Heemstra 1986, Sommer et al. 1996).
threats: Threats to this species are unknown, though it is likely to be taken as bycatch in some parts of its range.
population: No population data are available.
range: Cynoglossus acaudatus is known from KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa (Heemstra 1986), and probably Madagascar (Quero and Mauge 1989, Fricke et al. 2018). It has also been reported from off Somalia (Sommer et al. 1996, Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003) and the Seychelles (Heemstra 1986), but these records need verification. The report of this species from Nigeria (Taiwo et al. 2017) probably refers to another species of Cynoglossus (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2019). It is found at depths ranging from 47 to 175 metres (Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003).
useTrade: It is likely to be taken as bycatch in demersal trawl fisheries; however, no data are available regarding the extent of capture.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures; however, the range of this species overlaps with a number of marine protected areas such as Isimangaliso and uThukela Banks Marine Protected Areas, South Africa and Kiunga Marine Conservancy, Kenya (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2018).

rationale: This flatfish has a relatively narrow distribution in shallow, coastal waters of South Africa. No directed commercial fishery exists for this species, but it is harvested, especially in summer-time, in recreational fisheries and it may be a component of bycatch in inshore, demersal fisheries. No data are available to determine population trends at the species level at this time. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient. Recommendations to improve future assessments include obtaining better information regarding the distribution, population size and trend, habitat specificity, basic life history features, and exploitation rates.
habitat: This marine, demersal species inhabits relatively shallow, nearshore waters. Its diet consists of benthic invertebrates, primarily polychaetes (De Groot 1971, Thompson 2004). It reaches sexual maturity at 2 years and has a maximum reported age of 7 years. The protracted spawning season occurs from September-October to March-April. It is a batch, broadcast spawner with a fecundity of 34 ± 6 eggs per gram with an egg size of 1.38 ± 0.18 mm (Thompson 2004). The maximum recorded total length is 41 cm (Ende 2007).
threats: Population-level effects of exploitation are unquantified. As it is a coastal species, anthropogenic activities in these sensitive areas may negatively affect this species.
population: Population data are limited. It may be locally abundant (Smith 1961).
range: This species is known only from southern Africa, from Knysna to Delagoa Bay (Boulenger 1900, Smith 1961, Heemstra and Gon 1986, Heemstra and Heemstra 2004, Vachon et al. 2008, Okamoto and Motomura 2021). It has been reported from the Western Pacific Ocean (e.g., Ochiai 1984, Iwatsuki et al. 2000, Munroe 2001, Sakai et al. 2001, Allen and Adrim 2003, Shao et al. 2008, Cabanban et al. 2010, Kottelat 2013, Nakabo and Doiuchi 2013, Muto 2019), but these records are based on misidentifications of Brachirus aspilos according to Okamoto and Motomura (2021). Although specific depth records are not available, it is often found in very shallow water (less than 2 m: Smith 1961, Heemstra and Gon 1986).
useTrade: Limited information is available regarding the exploitation of this species. Recreational fishers spear soles, including this species, while wading in shallow waters. It was selected as a suitable candidate for aquaculture attempts due to its relatively large size, shallow depth distribution, and relative abundance (Thompson 2004). Further research is needed to determine its reproductive biology to better inform aquaculture interests (Ende 2007, Thompson et al. 2007).
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place. It may occur in marine protected areas in South Africa.

rationale: This species is listed as Critically Endangered (A2d+3d+4d). It is inferred that populations have declined by 80% over the past 21 years (three generations, generation length estimated at seven years, i.e. 1998-2019) based on overexploitation from hunting and poaching (A2d). Being precautionary, the species is listed as Critically Endangered (A3d+4d), both looking forward three generations (2019-2040) and looking backward one generations and forward two generations (2012-2033). This is based on very high levels of harvest for commercial trafficking of live and dead individuals, industrially processed frozen pangolins, and scales, seemingly across the species’ range, combined with ongoing exploitation for local use. Quantifying the extent of exploitation spatially is difficult but it seems likely that Singapore and smaller islands (e.g., those surrounding mainland and island Southeast Asia in the species’ range) may be the only localities where overexploitation is not a threat. This predicament is compounded by a number of factors including the likelihood that governance and law enforcement changes on a level needed to prevent the overexploitation of the species are unlikely to occur within three generations time. Additionally, there is currently weak evidence that demand reduction efforts in key consumer countries for Asian pangolin products and derivatives, which theoretically could lead to a reduction in harvest, are effective. Meanwhile, the incentives for harvesting and illegally trading in the species are universally high based on the high financial value of pangolin parts and derivatives.
habitat:
